name: Turin
fun_fact: Fun fact: Turin is the birthplace of Nutella! Pastry chef Pietro Ferrero invented it in 1951 as 'SuperCrema' during World War II cocoa shortages, using Piedmont's famous hazelnuts. Turin also produces 40% of all Italian chocolate (85,000 tons annually) and is home to gianduiotto, the legendary chocolate-hazelnut confection created in 1865 that inspired Ferrero Rocher.

hero_dishes.name: Gianduiotto Chocolate
hero_dishes.description: Small boat-shaped chocolates wrapped in golden foil, made from cocoa and Piedmont's prized Tonda Gentile delle Langhe hazelnuts. These have a creamy, buttery texture and intense aroma that set them apart from any other chocolate.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in 1865 by Michele Prochet and Caffarel during cocoa shortages. The chocolate is named after Gianduja, Turin's traditional Commedia dell'arte characterâ€”a charming gentleman in a brown jacket and yellow waistcoat who carries wine. When cocoa imports were restricted, local confectioners mixed ground Piedmont hazelnuts with the limited cocoa, creating magic.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Caffarel (the original maker since 1865), Baratti & Milano (historic cafÃ© founded 1858), Guido Gobino, Peyrano, and the elegant cafÃ©s along Via Po and Piazza Castello. Turin's Porta Palazzo Market is Europe's largest open-air market for fresh ingredients.

hero_dishes.name: Bicerin
hero_dishes.description: Turin's iconic layered drink meaning 'small glass' in Piedmontese. Three distinct layers: 1/3 rich hot chocolate, 1/3 strong espresso, 1/3 whipped cream on top. Served in a small glass to showcase the beautiful stratification.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in the 18th century and served at CaffÃ¨ al Bicerin since 1763. Camillo Cavour, one of Italy's founding fathers, famously started every day with a bicerin at this legendary cafÃ© in Piazza della Consolata.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: CaffÃ¨ al Bicerin dal 1763 (the original, open since 1763), CaffÃ¨ Fiorio (once frequented by writers and heroes of the Risorgimento), CaffÃ¨ Mulassano (for traditional Torinese experience with vermouth and tramezzini).

hero_dishes.name: Agnolotti del Plin
hero_dishes.description: Tiny hand-pinched pasta pockets ('plin' means pinch in Piedmontese) traditionally filled with roasted meats, braised in Barolo wine, and served with butter and sage or meat jus.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This is Piedmont's signature pasta, representing the region's connection to its farming heritage and the tradition of using every part of the animal. Each restaurant guards its own family recipe.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Del Cambio (historic restaurant in Piazza Carignano with refined Piedmontese cuisine), Magorabin (contemporary interpretations), Consorzio (modern, emphasizes lesser-used cuts), Piola da Cianci (no-frills trattoria with generous portions and house wine carafes).

hero_dishes.name: Vitello Tonnato
hero_dishes.description: Thinly sliced cold veal topped with a creamy tuna-caper sauce. Despite the unusual combination, it's a beloved Piedmontese classic.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional Piedmontese antipasto that showcases the region's love for elegant, refined flavors and surprising ingredient pairings.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: L'Acino (Michelin-recognized 'Restaurant Wine Gallery'), Del Cambio, and traditional trattorias throughout Turin's historic center.

signature_drinks.name: Vermouth
signature_drinks.description: Turin is the birthplace of commercial vermouth. This aromatized, fortified wine is infused with botanicals from the Alpine foothills and strengthened with unaged brandy for longer shelf life.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals enjoy vermouth as an aperitif before dinnerâ€”'Extra Vermouth' pairs the drink with local dishes in tasting sessions. CafÃ© Mulassano is famous for vermouth and tramezzini. Vineria i 3 Galli in the Quadrilatero district serves vermouth with Piedmont cheeses.

signature_drinks.name: Barolo and Barbaresco Wine
signature_drinks.description: World-class red wines from nearby Langhe vineyards, made from Nebbiolo grapes. Barolo is known as 'the king of wines and the wine of kings.'
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: These powerful, tannic wines are paired with rich Piedmontese dishes like brasato (beef braised in Barolo), tajarin pasta, and aged Castelmagno cheese. Wine bars like Vineria i 3 Galli and Consorzio (renowned for natural wines) showcase local vintages.

food_culture_notes: Turin has been the chocolate heart of Europe since the 17th century when chocolatiers made artisan delicacies for the House of Savoy royal dynasty.
The city's opulent, centuries-old cafÃ©s like CaffÃ¨ Al Bicerin and CaffÃ¨ Fiorio are institutionsâ€”visiting them is like stepping into the Risorgimento era.
Piedmont hazelnuts (Tonda Gentile delle Langhe) are considered the world's finest, with lower bitterness and superior creamy, buttery texture.
Antonio Benedetto Carpano created commercial vermouth in Turin using abundant Alpine botanicalsâ€”the drink became synonymous with Italian aperitivo culture.
The tradition of 'Extra Vermouth' brings together the drink and local dishes for a perfect aperitif pairing experience.
Turin invented the first hot chocolate houses, chocolate spread, and modern chocolate production techniques.
